questions.question_text:
A company's Architect needs to find an efficient way to get data from an external partner, who is also a Snowflake user. The current solution is based on daily JSON extracts that are placed on an FTP server and uploaded to Snowflake manually. The files are changed several times each month, and the ingestion process needs to be adapted to accommodate these changes.

What would be the MOST efficient solution?

choices.B: Ask the partner to use the data lake export feature and place the data into cloud storage where Snowflake can natively ingest it (schema-on-read).
choices.A: Ask the partner to create a share and add the company's account.
choices.C: Keep the current structure but request that the partner stop changing files, instead only appending new files.
choices.D: Ask the partner to set up a Snowflake reader account and use that account to get the data for ingestion.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
already the other user is a snowflake user, so share would be the optimal solution.

Selected Answer: A
json is prepared from some table(tables) and extracts to FTP. they can create a share with secure view which will contain all data with logic in place

Selected Answer: B
A. No, users sharing a share that includes a database cannot see the files contained in an stage within that database by default.

questions.question_text:
Based on the architecture in the image, how can the data from DB1 be copied into TBL2? (Choose two.)

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A & E are right answers.

Selected Answer: AE
AE should be the correct as the have the complete paths

A & E are correct answers.
C is missing complete path for @STAGE, since schema is using SH2 and stage is in schema DB1.SH1.STAGE1
A & E are the only ones with qualified names that will work

questions.question_text: Why might a Snowflake Architect use a star schema model rather than a 3NF model when designing a data architecture to run in Snowflake? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
agreed with NachoPrendes

Selected Answer: DE
A. Snowflake handle the joins perfectly
B. data duplication is bigger in Star Schema
C. The landing zone receives the data "AS IS", without changes

choices.E: The Architect wants to present a simple flattened single view of the data to a particular group of end users.
choices.D: The BI tool needs a data model that allows users to summarize facts across different dimensions, or to drill down from the summaries.
choices.A: Snowflake cannot handle the joins implied in a 3NF data model.
choices.C: The Architect is designing a landing zone to receive raw data into Snowflake.
choices.B: The Architect wants to remove data duplication from the data stored in Snowflake.

questions.question_text:
An Architect is troubleshooting a query with poor performance using the QUERY_HISTORY function. The Architect observes that the COMPILATION_TIME is greater than the EXECUTION_TIME.

What is the reason for this?

choices.C: The query is queued for execution.
choices.D: The query is reading from remote storage.
choices.B: The query has overly complex logic.
choices.A: The query is processing a very large dataset.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
unless it is a complex query, compilation time would not increase

Selected Answer: BD
I'd go with B and D. Option C is doable within a single tenant, and it might even save you money in certain situations, like zero-copy cloning.

C: Using separate Snowflake accounts for development, test, and production environments allows for tailored RBAC configurations without intermingling roles and permissions. This separation can simplify access management and enhance security, leading to cost-effective administration and compliance with organizational policies.
D: If the security policy requires different AD instances for various environments, maintaining separate Snowflake accounts is essential. This segregation ensures that each environment adheres to its specific security requirements, reducing complexity and potential security risks, thus optimizing costs related to security management and compliance.

choices.E: The company must use a specific network policy for certain users to allow and block given IP addresses.
choices.D: The company security policy mandates the use of different Active Directory instances for the development, test, and production environments.
choices.B: The company needs to share data between two databases, where one must support Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) compliance but the other one does not.
choices.C: The company needs to support different role-based access control features for the development, test, and production environments.
choices.A: The company wants to clone a production database that resides on AWS to a development database that resides on Azure.

questions.question_text:
A Snowflake Architect is designing a multiple-account design strategy.

This strategy will be MOST cost-effective with which scenarios? (Choose two.)
